  "translated_text": "Students' academic abilities vary tremendously. By the time they enter kindergarten, there are already differences in individual students' capabilities, and these differences widen further as they progress through elementary, middle, and high school. According to survey results published annually by the Ministry of Education, the number of students failing to meet basic academic standards increases significantly from elementary to high school.

In this situation, middle school teachers, and especially high school teachers, find it extremely difficult to conduct classes. 'What level of student should I tailor my teaching to?' is always a major concern for teachers. It's not easy to cater to either high-achieving students or low-achieving students. Therefore, teachers have no choice but to select 'average-level instruction.' This means somewhat arithmetically averaged instruction that as many students as possible can understand and participate in. High-achieving students may not find such classes very interesting because they already know the content being taught. For the opposite reason, low-achieving students won't be interested either.

To solve this problem, the Ministry of Education has decided to implement ability-based instruction starting in 2008, beginning with 7th and 10th grade students. Initially, students will be divided into upper, middle, and lower levels for English and mathematics classes, and textbooks will also be produced in three different levels according to ability.

The Ministry of Education expects that changing from the current uniform instruction to instruction tailored to students' levels will increase student satisfaction with classes. They believe this will reduce wasted class time and eliminate the problem of hagwon education [Korea's private tutoring industry] costs that arise from students taking school classes separately and hagwon classes separately. There are also expectations that this will have a positive impact on learning motivation, as students in lower-level classes can move up to intermediate or advanced classes based on their own efforts. Finland, which ranks first in the world for student academic achievement, is also said to be achieving results through public education alone without hagwon education, using ability-based customized instruction.

However, there are many challenges that must be resolved before 'ability-based instruction' becomes completely established. The opportunity costs involved in transitioning to ability-based instruction are enormous. There's the issue of discord among students, as well as the burden of needing additional classrooms for ability-based instruction and requiring about 1.5 times more teachers. Also, if students' efforts to 'ascend' to advanced classes become excessive, hagwon education focused on preparing for advancement to higher-level classes could actually increase.

'Assessment' also seems likely to be an important key determining the success or failure of ability-based instruction. It's said that school records [GPA] will carry greater weight in university admissions [college entrance exams] going forward, but how to evaluate and compare students who have been taught by different teachers using different textbooks seems like a far from easy problem."

High-income parents spend on average more than 3 times as much on hagwon education [Korea's private tutoring industry] as low-income parents. Students' CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] scores also show large differences based on parents' educational background. Children of high school graduate parents score 294 points. If middle school graduates, 279 points. That's a difference of as much as 56 points.

This shows that CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] score gaps ultimately occur based on parents' economic power. The problem is that this vicious cycle of educational inequality continues repeatedly. Sustained attention is needed for low-income children who have relatively outstanding academic achievement abilities.

<Anchor> There isn't much time left until the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] now, is there? [Tae Ki-yeon/High School Senior: Since time is very limited, I'm reducing sleep to study, which is physically very burdensome.]

President Roh said "I met with Prime Minister Hun Sen and met the Speaker of the National Assembly and other leaders, and they are all leaders who stood on the people's side and devoted themselves at risk during times when people were killed and suffered under violent regimes," adding "The leaders of this country are still continuously respected."
